benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/catalog/availableBasePlans - Retrieve available base plans

covered: Valid requests: TC01 and TC02 validate successful retrieval with and without accountId (200 + application/json + PlanDetail array).
Empty responses: TC03 and TC14 verify behavior when the catalog is empty (200 with empty JSON array).

Query parameter handling and input validation: TC02, TC04, TC05, TC08 exercise valid/invalid accountId, non-existent accountId, unsupported params, and indicate expected 400/422 behavior for bad formats.
Authorization (basic): TC06 covers unauthenticated/invalid-token requests returning 401.
Error and resilience scenarios: TC07 (catalog service down -> 503), TC17 (timeout -> 504), and TC16 (degraded dependent service -> 200/206) cover service failure modes.
Security: TC12 and TC13 test SQL injection and XSS attempts on accountId and assert no sensitive leakage and proper validation.
Performance and scale: TC09 (100 plans), TC10 (concurrent requests), and TC11 (very large catalog) exercise normal/peak loads and large payload handling.
Backward compatibility and integration: TC15 ensures compatibility with previous client patterns; TC16 covers partial data from dependent systems.
Response validity and accessibility: TC18 asserts valid JSON and machine-readable response structure.
gaps: Pagination: No tests for pagination parameters or behavior (limit/offset/page, Link headers, paged responses) when result sets are large.
Caching and conditional GETs: No tests for ETag, If-None-Match, Last-Modified, Cache-Control, 304 Not Modified, or cache-related headers.
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests for client rate limits (429 responses) or system throttling behavior under bursts.
Authorization granularity / 403: No tests for authorized-but-forbidden scenarios (403), token scopes, role-based access, tenant isolation, or token expiry handling.

PlanDetail contract/schema: Tests assert required fields in general but do not perform strict schema/type validation (data types, enums, nested pricing/billing structures, required vs optional fields).
Response headers beyond Content-Type: No assertions for Content-Length, Vary, Link (pagination), Retry-After, or other operational headers.

Error payload consistency: Lack of tests for consistent error body schemas and exact status-code semantics across error cases (e.g., 400 vs 422 vs 500), and absence of checks for sensitive data leakage in all error responses.
Unsupported methods and content negotiation: No tests for unsupported HTTP methods (405 Method Not Allowed) or Accept header negotiation (e.g., 406).
Tenant-specific catalog variations: Background mentions tenant-specific catalogs but there are no explicit tests validating per-tenant catalog isolation or tenant-scoped filtering.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: verify limit/offset/page parameters, Link headers (next/prev), proper counts/metadata, and behavior when clients request out-of-range pages.
Add caching and conditional GET tests: verify ETag and Last-Modified behavior, If-None-Match/If-Modified-Since requests, Cache-Control headers, and correct 304 responses to reduce bandwidth.
Implement rate-limiting tests: simulate request bursts to validate 429 responses, Retry-After header, and graceful degradation under throttling.
Expand authorization tests: include 403 scenarios (authorized but forbidden), token scope and expiration tests, tenant isolation checks, and role-based access control cases.

Add strict PlanDetail schema validation using JSON Schema or contract tests: verify field data types, required vs optional fields, allowed enum values, nested structures (pricing, billing period), and sample boundary data.
Validate additional response headers: assert presence and correctness of operational headers such as Content-Length, Vary, Link, Retry-After, and Cache-Control.
Standardize and test error payloads: define expected error schema and assert it across different error codes; ensure error messages never leak sensitive info or internals.
Add unsupported-method and content negotiation tests: verify POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE return 405 where appropriate and Accept header variations are handled (406 or fallback).
Define SLAs for performance tests and make assertions against numeric thresholds (e.g., response time percentiles under load) rather than vague expectations.
Include focused tenant-specific tests: seed multiple tenant catalogs and verify correct catalog isolation and accountId-to-tenant resolution behavior.
